newsitem.title: USA: CSCE coffee called to open 1.00-2.00 cents lower.
newsitem.headline: CSCE coffee called to open 1.00-2.00 cents lower.

text.p: CSCE coffee futures were called to open 1.00 to 2.00 cents lower Monday, based on a weak performance in London, traders said.
LIFFE robusta futures were mostly lower at midday Monday after a firm start, with July down $15 at the break at $1,742 after ranging from $1,765 to $1,732.

Friday, New York arabica futures ended mostly higher in thin, rangebound dealings. July closed up 1.00 cent at 218.00 cents a lb after ranging between 218.50 and 214.75. Spot May fell 1.00 cents to 239.00 cents, while the back months closed 1.05 higher to 1.00 lower.
The May/July switch narrowed to 21.10 cents from 23.10 cents at the close on Thursday. The July/September switch was steady, ending at 22.35 cents compared with 22.40 cents on Thursday.

On the charts, traders pegged near-term July resistance at 219.00-220.00, followed by 225.00, its life-of-contract high. July near-term support was seen at 214.50, followed by a strong downside hurdle at 209.00.
After Friday's close, CSCE reported certified coffee stocks increased by 1,500 bags, to 26,919 bags as of May 8. There were 16,615 bags of coffee pending grading, the exchange said.
CFTC's Commitments of Traders report for the two weeks ended May 6 showed noncommercial long positions rose 93 lots to 7,536 lots, while noncommerial short positions rose 138 lots to 978 lots.
Commercial long positions in the two weeks fell 1,064 lots to 7,663 lots, and commerial short positions fell 530 lots to 17,965 lots.
Non-reportable long positions rose by 823 lots, to 13,026 lots, while nonreportable short positions rose by 244 lots to 9,282 lots.
